title.narrative: ENABLING ENVIRONMENT NUTRITION

description.narrative: By 2022, MoHS and other partners at national and sub-national level, including non-state actors, have increased capacity to legislate, plan and budget effectively for the scaling-up of evidence-based nutrition specific interventions with equity, which contributes to Operations Support To Programme Delivery, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition, Treatment Of Severe Acute Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Evaluations, Research And Data, Harnessing Power Of Business And Markets, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, more children under 5 and women of reproductive age equitably access and utilize evidence-based health, HIV & nutrition interventions, including adoption of key behaviours, especially among vulnerable populations in most deprived states/regions, conflict-affected and peri-urban areas (Goal Area 1 UNICEF Strategic Framework 2018-2021)

sector.narrative: Breastfeeding protection, promotion and support (including work on Code)
Data, research, evaluation, evidence generation, synthesis, and use for SAM and nutrition in emergencies
Data, research, evaluation, evidence generation, synthesis, and use for prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition
Diet diversity in early childhood (children under 5), includes complementary feeding and MNPs
Maternal nutrition, including information, supplementation and counselling
National multisectoral strategies and plans to prevent stunting (excludes intervention-specific strategies)
Prevention of overweight and obesity in early childhood (children under 5)
Risk informed programming including climate resilience disaster and conflict
Salt iodization and other large-scale food fortification
Technical assistance - Prevention of stunting and other forms of malnutrition

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, MoHS and other partners at national and sub-national level, including non-state actors, have increased capacity to legislate, plan and budget effectively for the scaling-up of evidence-based nutrition specific interventions with equity

description.narrative: With UNICEF's continued advocacy and support, progress was made in development and costing of Maternal, Infant and Child Nutrition implementation plan. During COVID-19 Pandemic, Nutrition in Emergency programming guidance was adapted, developed and implemented. Nutrition legislation particularly on Breast-milk substitute (BMS) code and monitoring of iodised salt was strengthened, and Human Milk Bank as well as Workplace lactation support programme were established. However effective enforcement in BMS code and iodized salt law remains limited and will be prioritised in 2020. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:30/07/2020

title.narrative: Existence of a functional national coordination body for the control of iodine deficiency disorders

Existence of a national nutrition policy that includes prevention or reduction of stunting (1=no strategy, 2=draft strategy, 3=finalised strategy, 4=approved by Government, 5=includes Government budget line)
Adoption of the International Code on Marketing of Breastmilk substitutes as legislation and subsequent relevant World Health Assembly resolutions
Existence of a national management information system that includes disaggregated data on nutrition, including sex-disaggregated data
